utterances: It's always juggling, you know.
You know who you can pay late and who you absolutely can't.
Something as small as school pictures or a broken washing machine can keep her up at night.
I will literally take out pen and paper and go: What's flexible in the budget?
Food is flexible.
Spencer is not one to whine, as she puts it - perhaps because she's known better and she's known worse.
Back in the '90s, with a husband working as a carpenter, things were great, she says.
But everything changed when he suddenly walked out and Spencer ended up on public assistance.
I went from, you know, helping my clients apply for Medicaid to being there as a parent and experiencing the woman on the other end of the glass - you know, not even looking up.
Brutal, brutal.
Her rock-bottom was one day when her two girls - Katie and Gaelyn, who were nine and four - saw their mom in tears.
We were sitting out by the lake, and Katie says to me: We need Indian names, mom.
You'll be Standing Tall and I'll be Running Brave and Gaelyn will be Little One.
Okay, mom?
And I just - I came home that night, and I was just going: You know, I just need to be that person.
Newly determined and newly promoted at work, Spencer managed to get off public assistance and even buy a house by working overtime and watching every penny.
She wears prescription eyeglasses she found online for 8 bucks.
She gave up her phone line at home and just uses her cell.
And her daughters - who've been working since their first paper routes - are used to making do, like Gaelyn did last spring with a prom dress from a thrift store.
On good days, Spencer says, she sees it as character-building.
But it's good for them to see, you know.
It doesn't just come to you.
But, you know, I have my moments at three in the morning where I don't always look at it that way.
I will be honest with you.
Spencer says she especially sweats the big stuff, like sending two kids to college.
You really like this one?
Yeah.
My favorite.
Your favorite over UNH?
In the kitchen after school, Spencer pours through a pile of brochures she and Gaelyn collected at a college fair.
Well, I know.
I mean, the cheapest school is probably UNH, and then...
Well, that's my second-favorite, which is good.
Spencer nods silently.
This is a tricky thing for her, encouraging Gaelyn to follow her dreams, even if it means she'll graduate with a huge load of debt hanging over her head.
You'd live in a smaller apartment than you would - and you'd make car payments, and, you know, you do what your mom's done, you know, all of her life.
And you do what makes you happy, but you don't want your kid to struggle.
The Spencer girls know better than most what it means to struggle, and they're both driven because of it.
But they've also seen how even the best-laid plans can crumble, and that's taught them to let go a little, too.
I feel like it'll come, and we'll figure it out.
It's life.
Like, you can't really plan it.
That's just how it is.
You know, we do everything we can, and then the rest of this is out of our hands, just like it always is.
And then we sort of hope and pray for the best.
Tovia Smith, NPR News.
We're in a country where just about everybody thinks they're middle class.
If you're not sure you know what middle class means, you can test your knowledge at npr.org.
It's MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is one of the most popular and celebrated dance troupes in the world.
The company is now on a national tour.
Next week, the troupe performs in Miami.
And Miami's also the place where its new artistic director, Robert Battle, grew up in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods.
Reporter Jordan Levin was with Battle this week as he returned to the high school where he first got this start.
When Robert Battle was going to Northwestern Senior High in the mid-'80s, he'd walk 16 blocks to school through some of Liberty City's roughest neighborhoods.
The riot-scarred area was still wracked by drugs and crime and desolation, so the former boy soprano carried some protection under his dance tights and ballet slippers.
And I went to putting a hammer in my bag, because I was nervous about being picked on.
And it gave me a certain confidence, you know, that I could be tough when I needed to be and all of that stuff.
In fact, the hammer was in there so long I forgot it was in there.
And then the bag was so heavy.
I'm like, why is this bag so heavy?
When he walked into Northwestern this week, the only weight Battle was carrying was his position as artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
How are you?
Yes, I was waiting for you.
I was waiting.
Oh, my God.
How are you?
I'm good.
That's good.
I'm so proud of you.
That's Desiree Johnson.
She studied dance with Battle at Northwestern.
And now, her daughter is a dance student here.
I was so excited when she said, Mr. Battle is coming.
I said, I know who that is.
She said, how you know?
I said, we had it going on, so...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Well, could we do a reading?
We're joined now by Dr. Calvin Trent, Director of Detroit's Bureau of Substance Abuse Prevention Treatment and Recovery.
He joins us via phone.
And from member station WBEZ in Chicago, Dan Bigg.
He is a Director of Chicago Recovery Alliance, a coordinator of one the largest needle exchange programs in the country.
I thank you both.
Dr.
Trent let me start with you.
A lot of people have yet to hear of this epidemic.
And we should note while we mentioned three cities, this is growing and moving into other areas.
Baltimore is seeing a problem.
New York is starting to take a look at this.
How in fact did this come into the drug market?
Well you know in Detroit, we think that it has come in the drug market through Mexico, up into this area.
And that actually the product is - the fentanyl product is put into heroin before it gets to this community.
Dan Bigg one of the issues and problems that we're seeing is many of these addicts don't even know they are using this kind of heroin.
Well in effect, that's the nature of illicit drug use in the United States - is you don't know what you're using period.
And the warning of imminent death has been going on for 50 years with all kinds of drugs.
The more we more we make laws against them, the more it's a crap shoot.
Dr.
Trent, how do we stem this epidemic?
This is becoming more and more popular even with the danger.
In fact some of the street names - Bone Crusher and Get High or Die Trying - should speak to the issue of how dynamic this drug is.
Yeah, well there's two problems.
One is you know, the regular addict who unfortunately, and as Bigg says, will be looking to this to get a bigger high.
And that is one of the real issues in terms of addiction, that people are out of control, and they want to get high even in the face of death.
But also you know, we have what we call recreational drug users.
You know, people who come into town, and on the weekend, want to get high - and buy some illicit drugs on the street.
Which of course is a crazy thing to do.
But, we want to get a message to both those populations.
So our ad that you played is kind of intended for the recreational drug user, to kind of scare them off.
But we also had many people in recovery who have been out in the streets, in high drug-trafficking areas, trying to do face-to-face with addicts.
To warn them and to make sure that at least they use in groups, and don't use alone, and know what do in case of emergency.
Unfortunately, right now, we don't have a Narcan program.
But here at the health department, we are seriously looking at developing one in Detroit.
Dan Bigg, two points here.
One, we should note, that many of these users in fact do use drugs alone, so therefore they would not have anyone to resuscitate them if in fact they had an issue.
And let me ask you this question, how easily attainable is this drug?
And what's the cost for it?
